Well, tell me about the timing.
Was it just the right timing in your life to write a book like this or would - did it have anything to do with the changes we're going through now?

Well, it has to do with changes absolutely, both in the publishing industry, which is opening up and becoming more positively oriented to communicating information, both fiction and nonfiction using the comics medium, as well as I think changes in our society, challenges we're facing as far as scientific development and trying to reach out to get more people to understand science, in general, and in particular specific subjects like genetics which are going to have an increasingly - playing an increasingly large role in all our lives.

What offered - were the biggest hurdles, the biggest problems you had in tackling some of the material?
When you're dealing with Iraq, for example, Secretary Rice's issues in Iraq are not identical to Don Rumsfeld's.
She's there working on stabilizing the government on diplomatic issues.
He's worried about getting the situation under control and enforce protection.
And so we've purposely created a series of agencies who cooperate with one another but who also serve individual policymakers.
The CIA serves the president.
That's their policymaker.
And they also contribute to national intelligence activities.
But they are the largest body of what we call all-source analysts.
And if they're not functioning well, then it's very, very hard for John Negroponte to support the president.
And I think that's what we've seen play out is the feeling that the CIA was not working as well as people wanted under Mr. Goss, so therefore he stepped down.
And now they're sending in Negroponte's deputy to get the place up again.
Well, what happens when you've got the CIA coming up with, as what happened before the Iraq war, a very different picture of weapons of mass destruction than, let's say, what the Pentagon found?
Well, you know, part of the problem here is that we're not in the truth business in intelligence.
We're dealing with approximate reality.
And one of the reasons we have all of these agencies is that we recognize that it's very unlikely for one group of analysts to get the right answer all the time.
So we have this working methodology that we call competitive analysis.

By having different groups of analysts in different agencies with different points of view, military, civilian, energy, working on a problem, we feel we are more likely to come up with what's going on.
Porter Goss was in the post for less than two years.
How can intelligence-gathering function effectively when there's so much turnover at the top?
This is a recurring problem.
In fairness to Porter, Porter was the 19th and last director of central intelligence.
Nine of them served for two years or less.
It's a tough job.
Bottom line, I think most people listening to this want to know, are these people looking out for our best interests?
Are they effective in gathering intelligence that will make me safe?
Yes, but it's not perfect.
Intelligence is not necessarily going to prevent every attack.
I think one of the saddest things that happened when they created Ambassador Negroponte's job was the way it was oversold to the American public.
All these people saying, well, now that we've created this job, we're safe.
I mean, I have this vision of Osama bin Laden sitting in his cave some place saying, darn, they created a DNI.
We're in trouble.
DNI being director of national intelligence.
Yes, they're very good at what they're doing and they're sorting this out.
They're also sorting out the difficulty working against an issue for which they were not structured to work on.
The structure we have evolved over the Cold War.
And we are still sort of changing direction to focus on this very different kind of issue.
And it's not anyone's fault.
It's just that the issues have changed.
